intro: Commiphora lugardae, commonly known as the KwaZulu-Natal myrrh, is a small evergreen shrub native to the subtropical regions of South Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh trees. The plant produces a resinous sap that has been traditionally used for its aromatic and medicinal properties. Its leaves are elliptical, leathery, and have a distinctive glossy appearance. The plant's botanical significance lies in its role as a source of natural resins and its ecological importance in its native habitat.
